text: Spanish dialects don't change very much.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Slang changes a lot, but Spanish is pretty standard.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: It's not like Arabic, for example, where you have such a different Arabic in Morocco to Egypt, for example.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: All of the different Spanishes are completely mutually intelligible, but in slang you get many different terms and words, and car is one of these words that have different versions.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: You might hear dinero, which is like the standard word.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: You might hear plata, which actually means silver.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Pasta, you might hear pasta, that's one.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So we had a few words for car.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Do you remember any of them?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: How would you say the car?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And how would you say a car?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So it's a masculine word and we use el for the and un for a.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: What if we say the cars?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So the plural of el is los.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: The word for expensive is carro.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So it's like carro, but with one R.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So again it's a nice pair to feel the difference between having the single R and the double R, just as we saw in pero, meaning but, and perro, meaning dog.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So how would you say the car is expensive?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So es, we said was it is, she is, he is, or just is, or you are talking to usted, talking formally.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So if you just wanted to say it is expensive?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And what if you are talking about a feminine thing?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And when I say feminine thing, I really mean a feminine noun, if you're referring in your mind to a feminine noun, because if you in your country call cars máquinas, then you're going to say es cara.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: But if you call them autos, then you're going to say es caro.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So it refers to the word more than the object, to the noun, the gender of the noun.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So es we have for is, and for they are, or you guys are, we know they always come together, we have son, son, S-O-N.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So if you want to say the cars are expensive, and we will use carro again.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: What if you use a feminine word like máquina?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: How is it going to be?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And the car is expensive, using again máquina.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: The word teacher in Spanish is professor, profesor.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So how would you say he is a professor?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And we don't need to say a, we can just say he is professor.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: What if you wanted to say she is a professor?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: What do you think might happen?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: What if you wanted to say they are teachers, and you mean a group of females?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So this is a noun, profesor.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: It's a word you can put the or a in front of.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Now, we said that adjectives, they change for gender if they end in o.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: For example, the global situation was.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So situación is feminine, but we're not saying globala.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Adjectives, these describing words that we can put is in front of, they only change if they end in o.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: But nouns, they can change to feminine, like profesor, profesora, to differentiate.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So this is why it's important to know what type of word we're dealing with.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: We're doing this already, but we don't even realize it.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: The moment we come in contact with a verb, we know exactly what to do.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: We know it's a verb and we know how to manage it.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: We don't start trying to make a verb masculine or feminine, for example.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So we're already making this differentiation, but we want to do it more consciously to get more control.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So this is a noun, doctor.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: What do you think that means?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So how do you think feminine, a female doctor would be?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So how would you say he is a doctor?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Now, if you want to get the plural of professor, profesor, or doctor, doctor, or any other word in Spanish that ends in a consonant, you don't add S, you add ES.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So how do you think it would sound, the plural of profesor?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So this is the plural for masculine or for mixed.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So how would you say they are professors?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And you mean a masculine or mixed group?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And if they were all female?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: They are doctors, mixed or masculine?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Words ending IVE in English, IVE, tend to become IVO, I-V-O for masculine singular.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: This is the one we always start from now and build from, this masculine singular or neuter, let's say.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, for example, addictive becomes adictivo.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Now, when I say neuter, we don't really have a neuter in Spanish.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: But the concept of neuter exists.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Let's say, for example, if I say it's addictive and I'm referring to living in the mountains is addictive, eating healthily is addictive or something like this, then I use the masculine singular.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So how would you say it's addictive?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: How would you say he is positive?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And you pronounce an S, where most English speakers will probably find themselves pronouncing a Z there because in English we have positive, positive.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So that would probably transfer into Spanish to positivo.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And we want to be careful not to do that.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: The word for very is muy, and it's spelled M-U-Y.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: The Y, you can imagine it like an eye.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Atractiva is showing us that it refers to a female.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So this would probably help us work out who we're talking about.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: But maybe we would want to say it to clarify or to emphasize or to contrast.
speaker: Speaker 1

speaker: Speaker 1

text: So I want you to spend some time to think about it and not guess.

text: I was thinking of the double G.
speaker: Speaker 2

text: Ah, well, these random double letters that we don't need in English, really, they just become single letters in Spanish.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So I think there's a double S there as well in English.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Well, that would also become singular.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: The only double letters that cross over are the R's and the N's.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: If you get a double F, double S, double G, these random double letters you get in English, they don't cross over into Spanish.
